covenant.name: The Covenant
covenant.category: Themes from Creation to the Division of the Kingdom

questions.question: In the biblical context, a **'covenant'** is best defined as a:
options: Legally binding contract between equal parties.
A solemn, binding agreement between two parties, often initiated by God.
A temporary promise that can be broken without consequence.
A set of suggestions for righteous living.
questions.explanation: A covenant is not a mere contract but a divinely established bond. It's solemn, binding, and unilateral in initiation (God sets the terms) while demanding a bilateral response (human obedience or faith).

questions.question: A key feature of a biblical covenant that distinguishes it from a simple contract is its emphasis on:
options: Relationship and commitment, often sealed with a sign.
Negotiation between parties of equal power.
questions.explanation: Biblical covenants create or restore a **relationship** (e.g., 'I will be your God, and you will be my people') and use visible signs (like the rainbow or circumcision) as perpetual reminders of the commitment, which transcend mere legal terms.

questions.question: The rainbow, circumcision, and the Sabbath are all examples of:
options: Signs that confirm and memorialize a covenant.
questions.explanation: These are not the covenants but the **physical tokens** used to confirm and commemorate God's covenantal promises to Noah (rainbow), Abraham (circumcision), and Israel (Sabbath, as a sign of the Mosaic Covenant).

questions.question: When God **'passes between the pieces'** of animals in Genesis 15, it signifies:
options: A self-maledictory oath, where God invokes death upon Himself if He fails the covenant.
A common cultural ritual for sealing friendships.
questions.explanation: This ritual (cutting a covenant) was a solemn act where the one passing through implied: 'May I be cut in two like these animals if I break this agreement.' Since God alone passed through, it highlighted the **unilateral, unconditional** nature of the covenant on His part.

questions.question: God's primary reason for sending the flood was:
options: To destroy all life and start completely over.
The widespread wickedness and violence of humanity.
To punish the serpent from Eden.
questions.explanation: Genesis 6:5 states that 'the LORD saw that the wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that every intention of the thoughts of his heart was only evil continually.' The earth was also filled with violence (Gen. 6:11).

questions.question: The Noahic Covenant was made with:
options: Only Noah and his direct descendants.
All of Noah's family and every living creature for all generations.
questions.explanation: Genesis 9:9-10 makes it clear that this covenant is unique because it is established not just with Noah and his offspring, but also 'with every living creature that is with you, the birds, the livestock, and every beast of the earth.'

questions.question: What was the sign of God's covenant with Noah?
questions.explanation: Genesis 9:13 identifies the **rainbow** as the 'sign of the covenant that I have established between me and all flesh that is on the earth.' It serves as God's visual promise of preservation.

questions.question: A key promise in the Noahic Covenant was that God would never again:
options: Allow sin to exist in the world.
Destroy all life on earth with a flood.
Make a covenant with all creation.
questions.explanation: Genesis 9:11 promises: 'I establish my covenant with you, that never again shall all flesh be cut off by the waters of the flood, and never again shall there be a flood to destroy the earth.'

questions.topic_focus: Man's Role in the Noahic Covenant
questions.question: What was man's responsibility in the Noahic Covenant?
options: To be fruitful, multiply, and govern life with respect (including the law against murder).
To build altars and offer sacrifices in every city.
questions.explanation: Man was given the command to be **fruitful and replenish the earth** (Gen. 9:1, 7). Crucially, the covenant also established the sanctity of human life and the penalty for murder, initiating the first basic laws of human governance.

questions.question: God's initial call to Abraham (then Abram) in Genesis 12 did NOT include a promise of:
options: A great nation and a great name.
That all peoples on earth would be blessed through him.
Numerous descendants as countless as the stars (given later).
questions.explanation: The promise of 'stars' was given later in Genesis 15, to reassure Abraham when he was without a biological heir. The initial call in Gen. 12:1-3 contained the three main components: Land, Seed (nation), and Blessing (universal).

questions.question: The sign of the Abrahamic Covenant was:
questions.explanation: Genesis 17:10-14 mandates **circumcision** as the 'sign of the covenant between me and you.' It was a perpetual, physical mark placed upon the male members of Abraham's household and future descendants.

questions.question: God changed Abram's name to Abraham to signify:
options: That he was now a prophet.
His new role as 'father of many nations.'
That he owned the land of Canaan.
His victory over the kings of the east.
questions.explanation: The name **Abram** means 'exalted father.' God changed it to **Abraham** (Gen. 17:5), which means **'father of a multitude'** or **'father of many nations,'** directly reflecting the central promise of the covenant.

questions.question: Who was the child of promise through whom the Abrahamic Covenant would be established?
questions.explanation: Genesis 17:19 explicitly states: 'Sarah your wife shall bear you a son, and you shall call his name **Isaac**. I will establish my covenant with him as an everlasting covenant for his offspring after him.' Ishmael was blessed but not the covenant heir.

questions.question: The promise that **'all peoples on earth will be blessed through you'** (Gen. 12:3) points ultimately to:
options: The coming of the Messiah, Jesus, from Abraham's line.
The military conquests of King David.
questions.explanation: The New Testament (Galatians 3:8) interprets this promise as the gospel itself—that through Abraham's most significant descendant, **Jesus Christ**, salvation and blessing would be extended to the Gentile nations.

questions.question: The Mosaic Covenant at Mount Sinai was primarily:
options: A unilateral promise from God without conditions.
A conditional covenant based on Israel's obedience to the Law.
A replacement for the covenant with Abraham.
questions.explanation: The Mosaic Covenant is **conditional**: 'If you will indeed obey my voice and keep my covenant, you shall be my treasured possession' (Exodus 19:5). Blessings (prosperity in the land) were dependent upon obedience to the Law.

questions.question: What did the people promise when they entered the Mosaic Covenant?
options: "We will love the Lord our God with all our heart."
"All that the Lord has spoken we will do."
"We believe in the promises to Abraham."
"We will conquer the land of Canaan."
questions.explanation: Exodus 19:8 records the people's response to the covenant stipulations: 'All that the LORD has spoken **we will do**.' This pledge was made three times, setting the conditional terms for the relationship.

questions.question: The core stipulations of the Mosaic Covenant are summarized in the:
questions.explanation: The **Ten Commandments** (or Decalogue, Exodus 20) are the ethical and religious summary of the entire Mosaic Law, serving as the fundamental requirements for Israel's relationship with God and one another.

questions.question: How was the Mosaic Covenant ratified and sealed?
options: With the blood of sacrifices sprinkled on the people and the altar.
With the circumcision of the Israelites.
With the parting of the Red Sea.
questions.explanation: Exodus 24:8 describes Moses sprinkling the **blood of the sacrifices** on the people, saying, 'Behold the blood of the covenant that the LORD has made with you in accordance with all these words.' Blood was essential for sealing this covenant.

questions.question: Deuteronomy 28 outlines the blessings for obedience and the curses for disobedience, showing this covenant was:
options: Conditional, with consequences tied to Israel's behavior.
Identical to the covenant with Noah.
questions.explanation: Deuteronomy 28 is the **'covenant sanctions'** chapter, explicitly detailing how God would bless and how He would curse. It’s the clearest example of a conditional covenant.

questions.topic_focus: Reason for the New Covenant Prophecy
questions.question: The prophet Jeremiah predicted a **'New Covenant'** because:
options: Israel had broken the Mosaic Covenant and needed a better one.
God had changed His mind about salvation.
The people demanded a new agreement.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:32 directly contrasts the New Covenant with the Old (Mosaic), stating, 'not like the covenant that I made with their fathers... my covenant that **they broke**.' The New Covenant was needed because of Israel's inability to keep the Old Covenant's demands.

questions.question: A key difference of the New Covenant, as stated in Jeremiah 31:33, is that God's law will be:
options: Written on stone tablets in a new temple.
Replaced by a new set of commandments.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:33 promises: 'I will put my law within them, and I will write it **on their hearts**.' This internal inscription contrasts with the external nature of the Law written on the stone tablets of the Mosaic Covenant.

questions.question: According to Jeremiah 31:34, a hallmark of the New Covenant is:
options: The necessity of a human high priest.
The universal and complete knowledge of the Lord and forgiveness of sins.
questions.explanation: Jeremiah 31:34 promises: 'For I will **forgive their iniquity**, and I will remember their sin no more.' This radical, complete, and permanent forgiveness of sins is foundational, leading to a new, personal knowledge of God for all members.

questions.topic_focus: Enabling Power of the New Covenant
questions.question: Ezekiel 36:26-27 associates the New Covenant with the gift of:
options: A new land with fertile soil.
A new heart and a new spirit, enabling obedience.
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 36:26-27 promises the gift of the Holy Spirit, which gives the covenant people both the desire and the ability to obey God: 'I will give you a **new heart**, and a **new spirit** I will put within you... and cause you to walk in my statutes.'

questions.question: The New Covenant is presented as:
options: A temporary fix until the old one can be restored.
A covenant only for the Gentile nations.
A slightly modified version of the Mosaic law.
questions.explanation: The New Covenant is **superior** (Hebrews 8:6) and **everlasting**, offering permanent forgiveness and a perfect High Priest, Jesus Christ. It fulfills the preparatory nature of the Mosaic Covenant.

questions.question: The sequence of covenants in the Old Testament shows God's unfolding plan to:
options: Create a series of independent and unrelated agreements.
Ultimately deal with sin and redeem a people for Himself.
Show His preference for one nation over all others.
Establish a purely political kingdom on earth.
questions.explanation: Each covenant builds upon the last, progressively narrowing the means (from Noah's family to Abraham's seed) and ultimately pointing toward the final solution for human sin—**redemption through the New Covenant in Christ**.

questions.question: A major implication of the Abrahamic Covenant is that God's salvation plan is:
options: Exclusive to the biological descendants of Abraham.
Intended to bring blessing to all nations of the earth.
questions.explanation: The promise in Genesis 12:3—'all peoples on earth will be blessed through you'—demonstrates that God's intention was always **universal**. This foreshadows the inclusion of the Gentiles in the New Covenant through faith in Christ (Galatians 3:8, 14).

questions.question: The Mosaic Covenant's primary function was to:
options: Provide a means of salvation through perfect obedience.
Reveal the holiness of God and the sinfulness of humanity.
Guarantee Israel's national prosperity regardless of their actions.
questions.explanation: The Mosaic Law, being perfectly holy and impossible for humans to keep perfectly, served to define sin and demonstrate humanity's need for a Savior. Romans 3:20 states that 'through the law comes **knowledge of sin**.'

questions.question: The promise of the New Covenant implies that the Mosaic Covenant was:
options: Temporary and preparatory, pointing to a greater solution.
Meant to be kept perfectly by Israel.
Identical in purpose to the New Covenant.
questions.explanation: The Mosaic Covenant was **temporary** (Galatians 3:19) and **preparatory**, acting as a 'guardian' or tutor to lead people to Christ by revealing their failure to meet God's standard.

questions.question: The concept of covenant is central to the Bible because it:
options: Provides a detailed history of the world.
Reveals God's character as a faithful promise-keeper.
Is only relevant to the Old Testament.
questions.explanation: The covenants are the framework through which God reveals His steadfast love, mercy, and **faithfulness** (Hebrew: *hesed*). They demonstrate that God is consistent and always keeps His sworn promises.

questions.question: Which covenant was made with all of creation?
questions.explanation: The **Noahic Covenant** in Genesis 9:9-10 is the only covenant established with 'every living creature' and the entire earth, guaranteeing the stability of the natural order (seasons, day/night) until the end of time.

questions.question: Which covenant was specifically conditional, with blessings and curses tied to obedience?
questions.explanation: The **Mosaic Covenant** (or Old Covenant) is the paradigmatic example of a **conditional** covenant. Its core promise—possession and blessing in the Land—was entirely contingent upon Israel's ability to keep the Law (Deut. 28).

questions.question: The promise of a specific land (**Canaan**) is most central to the:
questions.explanation: The Land promise is the physical aspect of the **Abrahamic Covenant** (Gen. 12:1, 7; 15:18). While the Mosaic Covenant governed life *in* the land, the Abrahamic Covenant established the irrevocable promise *of* the land to his descendants.

questions.question: Which covenant was ratified with a **blood sacrifice**, unlike the others listed?
questions.explanation: The **Mosaic Covenant** was formally dedicated by Moses sprinkling blood on the book and the people (Exodus 24:8; Hebrews 9:18-20), symbolizing the life required to seal the agreement.

questions.question: Which covenant focused on establishing a **holy nation** through a detailed legal code?
questions.explanation: The **Mosaic Covenant** (the Law, the Tabernacle system) was designed to make Israel a 'kingdom of priests and a holy nation' (Exodus 19:6), setting them apart from the surrounding nations through ritual and ethical purity.

questions.question: The Old Covenant (Mosaic) was written on tablets of stone, while the New Covenant is written:
options: On new stone tablets in heaven.
questions.explanation: This contrasts the external, visible law of the Old Covenant with the internal, spiritual Law of the New (Jeremiah 31:33), which is internalized by the indwelling of the Holy Spirit.

questions.question: Under the Mosaic Covenant, atonement was achieved through repeated animal sacrifices, whereas the New Covenant provides:
options: A once-for-all sacrifice through Jesus Christ.
questions.explanation: The Book of Hebrews emphasizes the supremacy of the New Covenant's atonement, noting that Jesus' death was a **single, perfect, and eternal sacrifice** that rendered all previous sacrifices obsolete (Hebrews 9:26; 10:10-14).

questions.question: The Mosaic Covenant primarily governed the ______, while the New Covenant creates a ______.
options: Nation of Israel; people of God from all nations
questions.explanation: The Mosaic Covenant was exclusively for the ethnic **Nation of Israel**, whereas the New Covenant creates a spiritual body composed of **people of God from all nations** (Galatians 3:28).

questions.question: Access to God under the Mosaic Covenant was mediated through priests, but in the New Covenant:
options: Access is direct through Jesus Christ for all believers.
It is still mediated through Levitical priests.
questions.explanation: The New Covenant establishes **Jesus Christ** as the one and only Mediator (1 Timothy 2:5) and High Priest, granting all believers direct, immediate access to God (the Priesthood of All Believers).

questions.topic_focus: Old vs. New: Knowledge of God
questions.question: Jeremiah 31:34 suggests a key distinction regarding the knowledge of God: in the New Covenant, it will be:
options: Based on studying the law more diligently.
Direct, personal, and universal among the covenant people.
Unnecessary because the law will be abolished.
questions.explanation: The prophecy states, '...they shall **all know me**, from the least of them to the greatest.' This points to a new, internal, and personal knowledge of God for every member of the New Covenant.

questions.question: The Mosaic Covenant could not produce true righteousness because it was dependent on human ability, while the New Covenant provides:
options: The power of the Holy Spirit to fulfill God's law.
questions.explanation: The New Covenant, as described in Ezekiel 36:27, is God's solution to human failure: 'I will put my **Spirit** within you, and cause you to walk in my statutes.' God provides the empowering agency that enables obedience.

questions.question: Which covenant is explicitly called **'everlasting'** in its initial establishment?
questions.explanation: The **Noahic Covenant** is called 'everlasting' in Genesis 9:16. The **Abrahamic Covenant** is called 'everlasting' in Genesis 17:7. The Mosaic Covenant, being conditional and temporary, is not described this way.

questions.question: The progression from the Mosaic Covenant to the New Covenant can be described as a move from:
options: A universal scope to a national scope.
questions.explanation: The Mosaic Law was **external** (stone), requiring human effort. The New Covenant is **internal** (heart), involving the transformation of the individual by the Holy Spirit.

questions.question: The story of Abraham being asked to sacrifice Isaac (Gen. 22) primarily demonstrates:
options: Abraham's blind faith and God's provision, confirming the covenant.
The end of the Abrahamic Covenant.
questions.explanation: The test confirmed Abraham's faith and resulted in God's provision of the ram, after which God re-swore the covenant promise (Gen. 22:15-18), cementing the covenant's certainty.

questions.question: Jesus at the Last Supper said, **'This cup is the new covenant in my blood'** (Luke 22:20), directly linking His death to the prophecy in:
questions.explanation: Jesus' statement, particularly the phrase **'new covenant,'** is a direct fulfillment and application of **Jeremiah 31:31-34**, which prophesied the establishment of a New Covenant ratified by His blood.

questions.question: A Christian understanding is that believers in Christ are:
options: Heirs of the promises made to Abraham.
Participants only in the Noahic Covenant.
Not part of any biblical covenant.
questions.explanation: Galatians 3:29 states that 'if you are Christ's, then you are Abraham's offspring, **heirs according to promise**.' Christians are spiritual heirs, inheriting the ultimate universal blessing of the Abrahamic Covenant through Christ.

questions.question: The **'law of God'** in the New Covenant (Jer. 31:33) is best understood as:
options: The same moral principles of God's character, now internally embraced.
A completely new and different set of laws.
The civil laws of ancient Israel.
questions.explanation: The New Covenant does not abolish God's moral standard; it provides the internal means (the Spirit) to truly fulfill it. The law written on the heart represents God's **unchanging moral character** and requirements.

questions.question: Which covenant served as a foundation for the others by establishing God's authority and His basic commitment to creation?
questions.explanation: The **Noahic Covenant** is foundational as it stabilizes the world and guarantees the continuance of nature (Gen. 8:22) for human and animal life. This stability is the necessary stage upon which God executes all subsequent redemptive covenants.

questions.question: The promise **'I will be your God, and you will be my people'** is a theme found in:
questions.explanation: This specific formula defines the relationship with the redeemed community and is explicit in the **Mosaic Covenant** (Leviticus 26:12; Exodus 6:7) and the **New Covenant** (Jeremiah 31:33; Ezekiel 36:28).

questions.question: The primary mediator of the New Covenant, superior to Moses, is:
questions.explanation: The Book of Hebrews establishes **Jesus Christ** as the Mediator of a better covenant (the New Covenant), whose priesthood and sacrifice are superior and permanent compared to the temporary mediation of Moses.

questions.question: The ultimate fulfillment of all God's covenants is found in:
options: The person and work of Jesus Christ.
The legal system of the Old Testament.
questions.explanation: Jesus Christ fulfills all the previous covenants: He is the promised Seed of Abraham, the Son of David, and the High Priest and perfect sacrifice of the New Covenant. He is the central reality of all God's covenant promises.
